And therfore I pray yow that in thys necessyte and in thys nede ye caste yow for to ouercome your herte. For Seneke saith / He that ouercometh his herte / ouercometh twyes / And Tullius sayth / Ther is no thyng so comendable in a grete lord as whan he is debonayr and meke / and appeesith hym lightly / And I pray you that ye wil now forbere to do vengeance in suche a manere that your good name may be kept and conseruyd. And that men may haue cause and mater to preyse yow of pyte and of mercy / And that ye haue no cause to
repente yow of thing that is doon. For Seneke saith He ouercometh an euyl maner that repenteth hym of his victorye / Wherfore I praye you lete mercy be in your herte / to theffect and to thentente that god almyghty haue mercy on yow in his laste Iugement. For seynt Iames saith in his epistlis / Iugement withoute mercy shal be do to hym that hath no mercy on an other wight.

WHan Mellebe had herd the grete skylles and resons of dame Prudence and her wise Informations and techinges his herte began tenclyne to the will of his wyf Consideryng her grete entente conformed hym anon̄ and assented to worke after her counceyll / And thanked god of whom procedeth alle goodnes and vertue / that hym hath sente a wyf of so grete discrescion. And whan the day cam that his aduersaryes shold appere in his presence He spack to hem ful goodly and sayde in this wise / Al be hit so that of your pryde and presumption and hie foly of your negligence and vnconnyng ye haue mysborn̄ you and trespassyd vnto me / yet for as mykyll as I se your grete humy •• te and that ye be sory and repentaunte of your gyltes hi • constreyneth me to do you grace and mercy / Wherfore I resseyue you to my grace and foryeue you vterly alle the offencys Iniuryes and wronges that ye haue don ayenst me to this effecte & to this ende that god of his endeles mercy will at the day of my dyynge forgyue me my gyltes / that I haue trespassed to hym in this world / For doubteles yf we be sory and repentaūt for our synnes and gyltes • the sight of our lord god is so fre & so mercyable that he wil forgieue vs our gyltes and brynge vs to the blysse that
neuer shal haue ende amen.
div.trailer: Here Endeth Chawcers tale of Mellebe & Prudence his wif & sophie his doughter. And begynnyth the Monkis Prolog.

lg.l: WHenne endid was the tale of Mellebe
And of Prudence & of her benignite
Our ost saide as I am feythful man̄
And be the precyous corpus madryan̄
I hadde leuyr thanne a barel of ale
That good leef my wif had herd this tale
For she is no thing of such pacience
As was this Mellebees wif Prudence
Be goddis bonys when I bete my knauys
She bringith me the grete clobbid stauys
And cryeth sle the doggis euerichon̄
And breke bothe bak and also boon̄
And yf that ony neyghbour of myn
Wol nat in chirche to my wif enclyn̄
Or be so hardy to her trespas
Whan she comyth hom she rampith in my face
And eryeth fals coward wreke thy wif
Be corpus dn̄s I wil haue thy knyf
And thou shalt haue my distaf & go spynne
Fro day to nyght she wol thus begynne
Allas she saith that euyr I was shape
To wedde a mylksop a coward ape
That wol be ouerled with euery wight
Thow darst not stonde be thy wyf a ryght
This is my liff. but yf that I wolde fight
And out atte dore. anone I moot me dight
And ellis I am lost. but yf that I
Be lik a wilde lioun fool hardy
I woot wel she wil do me sle som d • y
Som neyghbour and thanne go myway
For I am parlous with knyf in hond
Al be it that I. dar not her withstonde
For she is big in armys be my feith
That shal he fynde that here mysdoth or saith
But lete vs passe awey from this matere
My lord sire Monk he saith be mery of chere
For ye shul tellyn atale trewly
Lo rouchestr stondith here fast by
Ride forth myn owen lord breke not our game
But be my trouthe I knowe not your name
Whethir shal I calle you my lord dan Iohn
Or dan Thomas dan robert or dan al • on̄
Or of what hous be ye be your fadir kyn̄
I vowe to god thou hast a ful fair chyn̄
It is a gentil pasture there thou gost
Thou art nat lik a penaunte gost
Vp on my feith thou art som officere
Som worthy sexten or som celerer
For be my fadir foule as to my dome
Thou art a maistir when thou art at hoom̄
No poure cloisterer ne no poer nouice
But a gouernour wily and wise
And therwith of brawn and of bonys
A wel faring persone for the nonys
I prey to god yeue hym confusion̄
That first the broughte in to religion̄
Thow woldist haue be a tredefoule a right
Haddist thow as greet leue as thou hast myght
To ꝑfourme al thy lust in gendrure
Thou haddist begotyn̄ many acreature
Allas why werist thou so wide a cope
God yeue me sorou and I were pope
Not only thow but euery mighty man̄
Though he were shore vp on his pan
Shulde haue a wif for al this worlde is lorn̄
Religioun hath take vp al the corn̄
Of tredynge and borel men be shrympis
Of febil treys ther comyth wrecchid ympis
This makith that our heiris be so sklendir
And fe • il that they may not wel engendre
This makith that our wyuys wol assay
Religious folk for they may better pay
Of venus paiementis than mow we
Good woot no lussheburghs paye ze
But be not wroth my lord though I pley
Ful ofte in game a soth haue y herd say
This worthy monk took al in pacience
And saide I wol do my diligence
As fer as sowneth in to honeste
To telle you a tale or two or thre
And yf you list to harkyn hidi • ward
I wol yow sayn̄. of the lif of saint Edward
Or ellis tragedyes first wol I telle
Of whiche I haue an hundrid in my selle
Tregedy is forto telle a certeyn story
As olde bokis makyn memorye
Of hem that stondyn̄ in greet prosperite
And is falle out of his degre
In to mysery and endith wrecchidly
And they been vercifyed comynly
Of .vj. feet which men clepyn exametron̄
In prose eke ven enditid many ou
And in metre many a sondry wyse
Lo this ought ynough to suffise
Now harkenyth yf you list for to here
But first I beseche yow in this matere
Thogh I be ordre telle not thise thingis
Be it of popis Emperours & kyngis
And aftir her agis as men writen fynde
But telle hem som before and som behynde
As it comyth to my remembraunce
Haue me excusid of myn ignoraunce
lg.trailer: ¶.Here endith the Monkis prolog. ¶.Here begynneth the Tale.

lg.l: I Wil be waile in manere of tregedie
The harm of hem that stonden in hye degre
And fillen so that ther nas no remedy
To brynge hem out of her aduersite
For certen whenne that fortune list to fle
Ther may noman of her the cours 〈◊〉
Many a man ouerthrowen hath she
Beth waar be this ensampil yong and olde
Lucifer though he an aungil were
And nat a man at hym I wil begynne
For thy fortune may nat aungel dere
From high degre yet fyl he for his synne
Doun in to helle where he is yet ynne
O Lucifer brightist of aungellis alle
Now art thou sathanas that maist not twynne
Out of misery which thou art falle
Lo Sampson which was anunciat
Be the aungel longe or his natiuite
And was to god almighty consecrat
And stood in nobles whilech he mighte se
Was neuyr such another as was he
To speke of strengthe and therto hardines
But to his wyuys tolde he his secre
Thorough whiche he slow hym self for wrecchidnes
Sampson this nobil and mighty champioun
Withoute wepen saue his hondis twey
He slough and al to rente the lioun
Toward his weddynge walkyng be the wey
His fals wif coude hym plese and prey
Til she his counsel knew and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counsel gan bewrey
And hym forsook and took another newe
An hundrid foxis took Sampson for Ire
And al her tailis he to gedir bonde
And sette the foxis tailis al on fyre
For he in euery tayl. hath put a brond
And they brent alle the cornes in that lond
And her olyues and her vynes eek
A thousand men eke he slow with his honde
And hadde no wepyn̄ with hym but an asse cheek
When they were slayn̄ so thristid hym that he
Was wel nyhe lorn̄ for whiche he gan to prey
That god wolde of his pyne haue som pite
And sende hym drynk or ellis muste he dye
And of an asse cheke • hat was so drye
Out of a wang toth sprang anon awelle
Of whiche he drank Inowh shortly to seye
Thus halp hym god. as Indicum can telle
Be verry force at gasa on an nyght
Magre alle the Philistenys of that Cyte
The gatys of the toun he vp plight
And on his back y caryed hem hath he
High vp on an hille where as men myght se
O nobil and myghty Sampson̄ leef and dere
That strong worthy and nobil hath be
In all this worlde ne hath be thy pere
This Sampson̄ neythir sidir drank ne wyn̄
Ne on his hed cam rasour non ne shere
Be precept of the messanger deuyne
For al his strengthe was in his heere
Of his strength he had neuer pere
And .xx. yeer of ysrael he had the gouernaunce
But after sone shal he wepe meny a teer
For a womman broughte hym to myschaunce
Vnto his lemman dalida he tolde
That in his heris al his strengthe lay
And falsly to his foos hym she solde
And slepynge vpon a barm vpon aday
They made to clippe or shere his heer away
And made his fomen al his craft a spien
And whenne that they hym fond in such aray
They bond hym first and put out his yen̄
But or his heer were clippid or shaue
Ther was no bonde that mighte hym bynde
But now is he put in prison in a caue
Where as they made hym atte querne grynde
O nobil Sampson strengist of mankynde
O whilom Iugge in glorie and in riches
Yet neuer lyke to the I fynde
Sith thou art from wele falle in to wrechidnes
The end of this caytif was as I shal say
His somen maden a feste vp on aday
And made hym there beforn hem play
And this was in a tempil of greet aray
But atte laste he made a foul fray
For he two postis shook and made hem falle
And doun fil the tempil & al there it lay
And slow hym self and eke his fomen alle
This is to say the Pryncis euerichon̄
And eke a thousand bodyes weere there slayn̄
With fallyng of the greete tempil of stoon̄
Of Sampson wole I nomore sayn̄
Beth waar of this ensampil old & playn̄
That noman telle her cou •• eyll to her wyuys
Of suche thing as they wolde haue sec • ete fayn̄
Yf that hit towche her lymys or her lyuys
OF Hercules the souereyn conquerour
S • ngynge his werkis loude & high renoun
For in his tyme. of strengthe he baar the flour
He slo • gh and raft • the skynne of the lioun
And of Centaurus leyde the bost adoun
He arpies slough the cruel briddis felle

H •
〈◊〉 gol • yn applis rafte fro the dragon̄
He •• w out Cerberus the hound of helle
He sl •• gh the cruel tyraunt bu • urus
And m • de his hors to frete hym fles • h & boon̄
He slough the verry serpent venemous
O • Achilles two hornes brak he one
And he slough Cakus in a caue of stoon̄
He slough the geaunt Anthens the stronge
He slough the grysly be or and that anone
And baar his heed. vp on his spere longe
Was neuer wight sith the worlde began
That slough so many monstris as did he
Thorow the wide worlde his name ran̄
What for his strengthe and his bounte
And euery reme wente he for to se
He was so strong that noman mighte hym lette
And bothe worldis endis seith Thimothe
In stede of boundis he of bras a piler sette
A lemman hadde this nobil champioun
That highte deyanyra as fressh as may
And as clerkis make mentioun
She hath hym sent a sherte fresh and gay
Allas this sherte and wel away
Enuenemyd was subtilly with alle
That er he hadde werid it half a day
It made his flesh fro his bonys falle
But natheles som clerkis here excusyn
Be on that highte nessus that it maked
Be as be may I wol her not acusen
But on his body the sherte he werid al nakid
Tyl the flesh was for the venym slakid
And whanne he sawe non other remedye
In hoot colis he hath hym self rakyd
For with no venym deyned he to dye
Thus starf this worthy mighty hercules
Lo who may truste in fortune ony throwe
For hym that folowith al this worlde of prees
Or he be waar is ofte leyd ful lowe
Ful wise is he that hym self can knowe
Be waar for whanne that fortune list to glose
Thanne waitith she her man to doun throwe
Be such awey as he wold lest suppose
THe mighty trone the precyous tresour
The glorius septre and the ryal maieste
That hadde the kyng Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethe may discribid be
He twyes wan Iherusalem that cyte
The vessel of the tempyl he with hym lad
At Babilon was his souerayn see
In whiche his glory and his delit he had
The fayrest childryn of the blood ryal
Of Ierusalem he dede to gelde anone
And made ech of hem to be his thral
Among alle other daniel was one
That was the wisest child of euerychone
For he the dremys of the kyng expowned
There as in Caldey clerkys was ther none
That wiste to what fyn̄ his dremys sowned
This proud kyng let make a statu of golde
Sixti cubitis long and seuyn in brede
To whiche ymage. both yong and old
Commaundid he to loute and haue in drede
Or in a furneys. ful of flames rede
He sholde be ded that wolde not obeye
But neuer wolde acorde to that dede
Daniel ne his yonge felowes tweye
This kyng of kyngis proud and elate
He wende god that sittith in mageste
Ne myghte not bereue his astate
But sodenly he loste his dignite
And lik abest hym semyd forto be
And cet hey as an oxe and lay ther oute
In rayn with wilde bestis walkid he
Tyl a certeyn tyme was come aboute
And lik an eglis fetheris were his heris
And nayli • lik birdes clawis were
God releuyd hym at certeyn yeris
And yaf hym witte & than with many a teer
He thonkid god and euyr his lyf in feer
Was he to do amys or more trespas
And er that he laid was on his beere
H • knew that god was ful of myght & grace
HIs sone whiche that highte Balttasar
That held the regne aftir his fadir day
He ly his fader coude not bewaar
For proud he was of herte and of aray
And eke an ydolastir was he ay
His high astat assuryd hym in pryde
But fortune cast hym doun and there he lay
And sodenly his regne gan diuide
A feste he made vnto his lordis alle
Vp on a tyme he made hem blithe be
And thanne his officers gan he calle
G • th bryng forth the vesselis quod he
Whiche that my fadir in his prosperite
Out of the tempyl of Iherusalem beraft
And to our goddis thanke we
Of honour that our eldrys with vs laft
His wif his lordis and his concubynys
Ay dronkyn whilis her appetitis last
Out of thyse nobil vesselis sondry wynes
And on a wal this kyng his yen cast
And saw an hond armeles that wroot fast
For feer of whiche he quok and sighed sore
This hond that Baltasar made so sore agast
Wroot Mane. techel. phares and nomore
In al that lond magicien was ther non̄
That coude expowne what this letter ment
But daniel expowned it anon̄
And saide kyng. god to thy fadir s • nt
Glorye and honour regne tresour and rent
And he was proud & no thing god he dred
A • d therfore gret wrath god vp on hym sent
An hym berafte the regne that he hadde
He was out cast of mannys company
With assis was his habitation
And cet hey as a best in weet and dry
Til that he knew be grace and be reson̄
That god of heuyn hath domination
Ouer euery regne and euery creature
And thanne had god of hym compassion̄
And hym restoryd his regne and his figure
Eke thou that art his sone art proud also
And knowest alle thyse thyngis pryuyly
And art rebel to god and his foo
Thow drank eek of his vessels boldly
Thy wif eek and thy wenchis synfully
Dronk of the fame vesselis sondry wynys
And heryed fals goddis cursidly
Therfore to the shapyn greet peyne is
This hond was sent from god that on the wall
Wroot mane techel Phares trust me
Thy regne is doon̄. thow weyyst not al
Diuided is thy regne and hit shal be

To medes and to perciens quod
• e
And that same nyght the kyng was slawe
And Darius occupied his degre
Though he therto hadde neythir right ne lawe
Lordingis her by ensaumpil mowe ye take
How that in lordship is no sikyrnesse
For whenne that fortune wyl a man forsake
He berith awey his regne and his riches
And eke his frendis bothe more and les
And what man hath frendis thorough fortune
Mys hap wol make hym enemyes I gesse
This Prou • rbe is ful soth & ful com̄une
CEnobia of Belmarie quene
As writith Perceus of her nobles
So worthy was in armys and so kene
That no wight passid her in hardynes
Ne in lynage ne in non other gentilnes
Of kyngis blood of Perce is she descendid
I say that she had not most fiersnes
But of her shappe she myght not be amendid
From her childhoode I fynde that she fled
Office of womman and to wode she went
And many awilde hertis blood she shed
With arowis brood that she to hem sent
She was so swist that she anon hem hent
And whanne that she was elder she wold kylle
Liouns liberdis and hem alto rent
And in her armys welde hem at her wille
She durste wilde bestis dennys seke
And renne in the mounteyn̄ al the nyght
And slepe vnder abussh and she coude eke
Wrastil be verry force and verry myght
With ony yong man were he neuer so wight
There myghte nothing in her armys stonde
She kepte her maydenhede from euery wight
To noman deyned she to be bonde
But atte last her frendis haue her maryed
To Onedak a prince of a Cite
Al were it so. that she hem longe taryed
And ye shul vnderstonde how that he
Hadde suche fantesies as had she
But natheles when they were knet in • ere
They lyuyd in ioye and infelicite
For ech of theym hadde other leef and dere
Saue o thing that she nolde neuer assent
Be no wey that he sholde be her ly
But onys for it was her pleyn entent
To haue a child the worlde to multiplye
And also sone as she myghte aspye
That she was not with childe with that dede
Thanne wolde she suffir hym do his fantesie
Est sonys and nat but onys oute of drede
And yf she were with childe at that cast
Nomore shulde he pleye that game
Til fully .xl. daies were y past
Thenne wolde she onys suffir hym the same
Al were this Onedak wilde or tame
He gat nomore of here for thus she sayde
It was to wyuys lecherie and shame
In other caas yf men with hem playde
Two sonys be this Onedak had she
The whiche she kept in vertu and lettrure
But now vnto our tale turne we
I say that worshipfull creature
And wise therwith & large with mesure
So penibil in warre and curteys eke
Ne nomre labour mighte in werre endure
Was non. though al this worlde men shuld seche
Her riche aray mighte not be tolde
As w • l in vessel as in clothinge
She was al glad in Perry & in gold
And eke she lefte not for non huntynge
To haue of sondry tongis folk knowynge
Whenne that she leyser hadde and forto enten • e
To lerne bokis was al her likyng
H • w she in vertu her lif mighte dispende
And shortly of this story forto trete
So doughty was her husbond as she
That they conqueryd many regnes grete
In the oryent with many a feyr cite
Appertenaunt vnto the maieste
Of rome and with strenghte held hem fast
Ne neuer mighte her fomen do her flee
Al the whilez that Onedakis dayes last
Her batellis who so list hem forto rede
Agayn Sapor the kyng and other mo
And how al this proces fil in dede
Why she conqueryd & what title she had therto
And aftir of hir myshief and her woo
How that she was besegid and I take
Lat hym to my maistyr Petrark go
That writtih ynow of this I vndertake
Whenne Onedack was ded she myghtily
The remys held and with her owen hond
Agayns her foos she faught trewly
That ther nas prince ne kyng in al that londe
But were glad yf they that grace fonde
That she ne sholde vp on his lond werreye
With her they made aliaunce be bonde
To be in pees and lete hem ryde and pl • ye
The Emperour of rome Claudius
Ne hym beforn̄ the romayn Galiene
Ne durste neuer be so corageous
Ne non ermyn ne none egipcien
Ne furrien ne non arabien
With ynne the felde that durst with her fight
Lest that she wolde hem with her hondis sleen̄
Or with her meyne put hem to flight
In kyngis habit wente her sonys two
As heyris of here remys alle
And hermanno and titamallo
Her namys were as perciens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in her hony galle
This myghty quene may no while endure
Fortune made her out of her regne falle
To wrecchidnesse and to mysauenture
Aurilian whenne that he the gouernaunce
Of rome cam in his hondis tweye
He shoop vp on this quene to do vengeance
And with his legions he took his wey
Toward Cenobie and shortly forto seye
He made her fle and atte laste her hent
And fetherid hir & eke her childryn tweye
And wan the londe & hom to rome he went
Among othir thing that he wan
Her chare that of gold was wrought & perre
This grete romayn this aurilian̄
Hath with hym lad that for men sholde se
Beforn̄ his triumphe walkid she
With goldyn cheynes on her necke hanginge
Crowned she was as aftir her degre
And ful of Perre chargid her clothinge
Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredful to kyngis and to Emperouris
Now gawrith al the pepil on her allas
And she that helmyd was in sta • k shouris
And wan beforce townes strong & touris
Shal on her hed now were auetremyte
And she that bare the septre ful of flouris
Shal bere a distaf her cost forto quyte
OF Melan grete Barnabo viscounte
God of delite & scorge of lumbardye
Why shulde nat I thy fortune acounte
Sithen in estat thou clombyn were so hye
Thy brothir sone that was thy dowbyl alye
For he thy neuewe was and sone in lawe
With ynne his prison made the to dye
But why ne how woot I that thou were slawe
OF the erle Engelyn̄ of • ise the langour
Ther may no tunge telle for pite
But litil out of pise stondith a tour
In whiche tour in pryson put was he
And with hym his lityl children thre
The eldist skarsly .v. yeer was of age
Allas fortune it was gret cruelte
Suche briddis forto put in suche a cage
Dampned he was to deth in that prison̄
For roger whiche Bisshop was of pyse
Had on hym maad a fals • uggestion̄
Thorow whiche the pepil gan on hym aryse
And put hym in pryson in suche a wyse
As ye haue herd and mete & drynk he hadde
And therwith all it was ful poor & badde
And on aday it be fil that in that hour
When that his mete was wont to be brought
The gailer shitte the doris of the tour
He herde it wel but he saw it nought
And in his herte ther fil a thought
That they for hunger wolde do hym to dien̄
Allas quod he allas that I was wrought
Therwith the teris fille from his yen̄
His yonge sone that thre yeer was of age
Vnto his fader he sayde why do ye wepe
Whenne wol our Gayler brynge our potage

Is ther no morsel
• reed that the do slepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I mighte slepe euyr
Thanne sholde no hunger in my wombe crepe
Ther is no thing than bred that me were leuyr
Thus day be day this child gan to crye
Til in his fadris barm adoun it lay
And sayde far wel fader I mot dye
For this payne no lenger suffre I may
And whenne the woful fader ded hym say
For wo his armys he gan to byte
And sayde allas fortune and welawey
Thy fals whele my wo I may wyte
His othir child wende that for hunger it was
That he his armys gnew & not for woo
And sayde fader do not so allas
But rathir oet the flessh vp on vs two
Our •• essh thow yaf vs take our flessh vs fro
And ete ynough right thus the child sayde
And aftir that with ynne aday or two
The child leyde hym doun in his lappe & deyde
Hym self dispeiryd eek for hunger starf
Thus endid the mighty erle of pyse
• rom high estate fortune from hym carf
Of this tragedye it oughte I nough suffyse
Who so wil here it in a lengir wyse
Redith the grete poet of ytaile
That hight daunte for he can it deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt nat o word wil he fayle
AL though that Nero were as vicyous
As eny fende that lith ful lowe adoun
Ye he as tellith vs Snetomus
Al this worlde hadde in subiection̄
Bothe est and west and septemtrion̄
Of rubies. saphires and of perlis white
Were alle his clothis browdid vp and doun
For he in gemmys gretly gan delyte
More delicat. more pompons of aray
More proude was neuer Emperour than he
That ilke cloth that he hadde weryd o day
After that tyme he nolde it neuer se
Nettis of goold threed had he gret plente
To fisshe in tiber whenne he list to pleye
His lustis were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frend wolde hym obeye
He rome brent for his dilycacye
The senatours he slough vp on aday
To here how that wommen wolde wepe & crye
And slough his brothir & by his • uster lay
His moder made he in a pytous aray
For he her wombe slytte to be holde
Where he conceyued was so wel away
That he so lityl of his modir tolde
No teris out of his eyen for that sight
Ne cam but sayde a fayr womman was she
Gret wondir is that he coude or myght
Be domesman of her ded beaute
The wyn to brynge com̄aundid he
And drank anon̄ non other wo he made
Whenne might is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe wol the venym wade
In yonthe a maistir had this Emperour
To teche hym le • trure and curtesye
For of moralite he was the flour
And in his tyme but yf his bokis lye
And whilis his maister hadde of hym maistrie
He made hym so konnynge and so souple
That longe tyme it was or tirannye
Or ony vice durste in hym vncouple
Seneca his maistir was of which I deuyse
Be cause Nero had of hym such drede
For 〈◊〉 for his vicis wolde hym chastise
Discretly as by worde and not be dede
Syre he wolde say an Emperour moot nede
Be vertuous and hate Tyrannye
For whiche he made hym in a bath to blede
On bothe his armys til he must dye
This Nero hadde eek of a custumaunce
In yongthe ayens his maistir to ryse
whiche aftirward him thoughte a gret greuan̄ce
Be cause be ofte wolde hym chastyse
Therfore he made hym dye in this wyse
To chese in abath to dye in this manere
Rathir thanne to haue another turmentyse
And thus hath Nero slayn his maistir dere
Now fyl it so that fortune liste no lenger
The high pryde of Nero to cherisshe
For though he were strong yet was she strenger
She thoughte thus be god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfillid of vice
In his degre and an Emperour hym calle
Be god out of his sete I wol hym tri • e
Whanne he lest wenyth sonnest shal he falle
The pepil roos vpon hym on an nyght
For his defaute and whanne he it aspyed
Out of his doris anon he hath hym dight
Alone and there he wende haue be alyed
He knockid fast and ay the more he cryed
The fastir sh • t they the dorys alle
Tho wiste he wel he had hym self begilyd
And wente his way no lengir durste he calle
The pepil cryde and romblid vp and doun
That with his eris he herde how that they sayde
Where is this fals treiteur this neron
For feer ful neer out of his witte he breyde
And to his goddis pitously he seyde
For socour but it myghte nat be tyde
For drede of this hym thoughte that he deyde
An ran in to a gardyn hym to hyde
And in this gardyn fond he chorlis tweye
And sittyng be. a. fyre gret and reed
And to the chorlis two he gan to preye
To sle hym and to girde of his hed
That to his body whan he were ded
Weere no despyt doon̄ for his defame
Hym self he slough he coude no bettir re • e
Of whiche fortune lowhe and had game
WAs neuyr Capteyn vnder a kyng
That regnes mo put in subiection̄
Ne strenger was in feld of alle thing
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more Pompous in high presumpcion̄
Than Olophern̄ whiche fortune atte laste
So licorously ladde hym vp and doun
Til that • e ded was or that he wiste
Not only that this worlde hadde of hym awe
For lesing of riches and liberte
But he made euery man reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lord saide he
N • ne other god sholde honoured be
Ayens his heste ther dar no wight trespas
Sane in Betulia a strong cyte
W •• re Eliachim was prest of that place
But take kepe of the deth of Olophern̄
Amyd his ost he dronke lay al nyght
With ynne his tente large as is a bern̄
And yet for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudith a womman as he lay vpright
Slepinge his hed of smoot & fro his tente
Ful pryuely she stale from euery wight
And to the cyte she hath it sente
WHat nedith it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his high and ryal maieste
His high pryde his werk venemus
For such another man nas neuyr as he
Redith what that he was in Macha • e
And redith the proude workis that he leyde
And why he fil from his prosperite
And in an hill how wrecchidly he deyde
Fortune hym hadde enhaunsid so in pryde
That verily he wende he myghte atteyne
Vnto the sterris vp on euery syde
And in a balaunce to weye ech mounteyn̄
And alle the flodis of the se restreyn
And goddis peple hadde he most in hate
Hem wolde he sle in tourment and in peyn̄
Wenynge that god ne myghte his pryde abate
And for Nichamore and Timothe
Wiche Iewes were vencusid myghtily
Vnto the Iewes suche an hate had he
That he hadde gretthid his chare ful hastely
And swoor and saide ful despitously
Vnto Ierusalem. he wolde eftsone
To wreke his Ire on it ful cruelly
But of his purpoos was he let ful sone
God for his manace hym sore smoot
With inuisibil wounde ay nicurabyl
That in his guttes carf so and boot
That his peynys were Importable
And certenly the wreche was vnresonabil
For many amannys guttis did he peyne
But from his purpoos cursid & dampnabil
For al his smert. he nolde hym restreyne
But bad anon pareylen his oost
And sodenly or he than was waar
God dauntyd all his pryde and al his bost
For he so sore fil out of his chare
That alle his lymys and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myghte go ne ryde
But in a chayer men aboute hym baar
Al for brosid bothe bak and syde
The wreche of god hym smot so cruelly
That in his body wickyd wormys crept
And therwith al he stank so horribly
That none of alle his meyne that hym kept
Whethir that he wook or ellis slepte
Ne mighte not of hym the stynk endure
And in this myschief he wayled & eke wepte
And knew god lord of euery creature
To al his ost and to hym self also
Ful waltsom was the stynk of his ca • eyn
No man mighte hym • ere to ne fro
And in his stynk and in his horrible peyn̄
He start ful wre • chidly on a mountayn̄
Thus hath this robber & this homicide
That many a man made to wepe & playne
Such guerdon as belongith vnto pryde
THe story of alisaun • ir is so com̄une
That euery wight that hath discrecion
Hath herd sumwhat or al of his fortune
This wide worl • e as in conclusion̄
He wan / be strengthe and his renoun
They were glad for pees vnto hym sende

The pryde of man and
• oste he leyd a doun
Where so he cam in to the worldis ende
Comparison myghte yet neuer be makid
Betwix hym and another conquerour
For al this worlde for drede of hym hath quakid
He was of knyghthod aud of fredom flour
Fortune hym made the heir of high honour
Saue wyn & wommen no thing might a swage
His high entent in armes and labour
So was he • ul of louynge corage
What pite were it to hym though I you tolde
Of darius and of a hundrid thousand mo
Of princis. erlis. and kyngis. bolde
Whiche he conqueryd & broughte to woo
I say as fer as aman may ryde or go
The worlde was his. what sholde I more deuyse
For though I wrrote or tolde you euyr mo
Of his knyghthood it mighte not suf • yse
Xij. yeer he regned as I rede in Machab •
Philippis sone of Macedo he was
That first was kyng of grece that countre
O worthy gentyl A • saunder allas
That euyr sholde falle such acas
Empoysond of thy folk thow were
Thy strong fortune hath tournyd in to an aas
And for the ne wepte she neuer ateer
Who shal yeue men terys to compleyne
To the of gentilnesse and of franch •••
That all the worlde weldid in his demeyne
And yet hym thoughte it mighte not suffyse
So ful was his corage of high emprise
Allas who shal me helpe to endite
Fals fortune and poison to dispise
The which of al this woo I wite
GE wisedom manhood and high labour
From humbilheed and fro ryal maieste
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That al the occident be londe and see
Be strengthe of hond or elli • be ••• te
And vnto rome made hem t •• butary
And sith of rome Emperour was he
Tyl that fortune wey 〈◊〉 aduersary

O mighty Cesar th ••
〈◊〉 Thessaly
Ayens Pompeius 〈◊〉 thyn in lawe
That of the 〈…〉 al the chiualry
As fer as that 〈◊〉 begynneth to dawe

They þu thorou • h
•••• hthood hast take & slawe

Saue fewe fol •
〈◊〉 with 〈◊〉 fled ••
〈◊〉 which 〈◊〉 p •••• st al the orient in awe
Thanke fortun • that so wel the spedde
But now a litil while I wil bewayl
This Pompeius this nobil gouernour
Of rome whiche that fley at this bataille
I say on of his men a fals traitour
His hed of smoot to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and to hym the hed broughte
Allas Pompeye of the oryent conquerour
That fo • tune vnto such a fyn the broughte
To rome agayn repeyrith Iulius
With his triumphe laureat ful hye
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euiyr hadde of his high astat enuye
Ful pryuily hadde maad conspirefye
Ayens this Iulius in subtil wyse
And cast the place in whiche he sholde dye
With boydekyns as I shal you deuyse
This Iulius vnto the Capitoly went
Vp on ady as he was wont to gon̄
And in the Capitoly anon̄ hym hent
This fals Brutus on of his foul foon̄
And stikyd hym with boydekyns anon̄
with many a woun •• & thus they leet himlye
But neuer gruntyd he at no strook but oon̄
Or ellis at his wo but yf his story lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel louyd estatly • on • ste
That thought his dedly woundis so so •• smert
His mantel ouer his hippis cast he
For noman sholde se his priuyte
And as he lay in dy • nge on a tra •• c •
And wiste verily that dye shulde he
Of honeste hit hadde he remembraunce
Lucan vnto this story I recom̄ende
And to Sneton̄ and to valery also
That of this story writen word and ende
How that thyse conquerours two
Fortune was first frend & sithen foo
Noman truste vp on his fauour longe
But haue here in a wayte for euermo
Witnes on alle the conquerours stronge
THe riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde
Of whiche Cresus Citrins sore hym drad
Yet was he canght amyd al his peyde
And to brenne men to the fire hym had
But suche arayn̄ doun fro the firmament shadde
That queynte the fire and made hym to scape
But to be waar yet no grace he had
Tyl fortune on the galowis made hym gape
Whenne he ascaped was he coude nat stynte
Forto begynne a new aray agayn̄
He wende wel for that fortune hym sent
Suche that he a scapid thurgh the rayn̄
That of his foos he mighte not be slayn̄
And suche a sweuyn vp on a nyght he mette
Of whiche he was so proude & eke so feyn̄
That in vengeaunce he all his herte sette
Vpon a tre he was as hym thoughte
Th • re Iupiter hym wessh bothe hals & syde
And Phebus eek a fair towail hym broughte
To drye hym with & therwith wext his pryde
And to his doughter that stood hym besyde
Whiche that he knew in high sentence habounde

He
• ad her telle what it signified
And she his dremys right thus expouned
The tre quod she the galowis is to mene
And Iupiter betokenyth snow and rayn̄
And Phebus with his towel so clene
Be tokeneth the sonne bemys soth to sayn̄
Thou shalt an hangid be fadir certeyn̄
Rayn shal the wasshe and sonne shal the drye
Thus she warned ful plat and ful pleyn̄
His doughter that callyd was Phanye
An hangid was Cresus the proud kyng
His ryal trone mighte hym not auaylle
Tragedy is non other maner thing
Ne can in syngrye ne bewaylle
For that fortune alday wol assaylle
With vnwaar strook the regnes that be proude
For whenne men trust in her than wol she faylle
And couer her bright face vnder a cloude
lg.trailer: ¶Here endith the Monkes tale.

lg.l: HO quod our ooste syr nomore of this
That ye haue said is ynough ywis
And mykyl more for mykyl heuynes
Is right ynough to mykyl folk I ges
Your talis doon vs no disport ne game
Wherfore sir Monk Piers Adam be your name
I pray yow hertly tel vs sumwhat ellis
For sikirly nere clynkyng of your bellis
That on your brydil hongyn on euery syde
Be heuyn kyng that for vs alle dyde
I sholde or this fallen doun for slepe
Al though the slough hadde neuyr be so depe
Thanne hadde your tale al be told in ve •••
For certenly as thyse clerkis seyn̄
Where as a man may haue non audience
Not helpith it to telle his sentence
And wel I woot the substaunce is in me
Yf ony thing shal wel reportyd be
Sere say sumwhat of huntyng I you pray
Nay quod this monk I haue no lust to play
Now lete anothir telle as I haue told
Than spak our ost with mylde speche & bolde
And sayde to the Nonnys prest anone
Com ner thou prest com hidir sir Iohn
Tel vs suche thing as may our hertis glade
Be blithe though thou ryde vp on a Iade
What though thy hors be foul and lene
Yf he wol serue the recke the not abene
Loke that thy herte be mery euyr moo
Yes sir quod he so moot y goo
But I be mery I wis I wol be blamyd
And right anon his tale he hath attamyd
And thus he sayde to vs euerichon̄
This swete preest this gostly man sir Iohn
lg.trailer: ¶Here endeth the prolog of the Nonnys preest ¶And here begynneth his tale.

lg.l: A Poure wydow som deel stept in age
Was somtyme dwellyng in a cotage
Besyde a groue stondyng in a dale
This whidow of whiche I telle my tale
Syn that day that she was last a wyf
In pacience ledde a ful simpyl lyf
For lityl was her catel and her rent
By husbondrye suche as god her sent
She fond her self and eek her doughtryn two
Thre large sowys had she and nomo
Thre kyne and eek a sheep that highte malle
Ful soty was her bour and eek her halle
In whiche she eet meny a slendir meel
Of poynaunt sawce nedith her neuer ad • el
Ne deynte morsel passid thorow her throte
Her diet was accordaunt to her cote
Repleccion ne made hir neuer syke
A temperat diet was hir phisyke
And excercise and hertis suffisaunce
The gowte lete her no thing forto daunce
Ne replexion shente not her hed
No wyn drank she whyte ne red
Her bord was most seruyd with whit & blak
Milk & broun bred in whiche she fond no lak
Salt bacon̄ and somtyme an ey
For she was as amaner of a dey
A yerd she hadde enclosid al aboute
With drye stickis and dichid withoute
In whiche she hadde a cok highte chaunte • leer
In al the lond of crowyng nas his peer
His wis was merier than the mery orgon̄
On masse dayes that in chirche goon̄
Wel sikerer was his crowyng in his loge
Thanne is a clocke or in ony abbey an orloge
Be nature he crewe eche assencion̄
Of the equynoccion in the toun
For whenne degrees .xv. were ascendid
Than crew he that it mighte not be amendid
His comb was redder than the fyn coral
And batellid as it had be a castel wal
His bil was blak as ony geet it shoon̄
Lik asure were his leggis and his toon
His naylis whitter than the lily flour
And lik the burned gold was his colour
This g • ntil cok hadde in his gouernaunce
Seuen •• nnys to do with his plesaunce
Whiche were his sistris and his paramouris
And wonder lik to hym as of colouris
Of whiche the fairist he wid in the throte
Was clepid faire damysel Pertelote
Curteys she was discreet and debonaire
And compenabil and baar hir self so faire
S • n that tyme that she was seue nyght olde
That trewlich she hath the herte in hold
Of chaunte cleris lokyng in euery lith
He loueth her so that wel was hym therwith
Whan the bright sonne gan to sprynge
Hit was a melodye to here hem synge
In swete accorde my leef is fare in londe
For that tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Bestis and briddis coude speke and synge
And so it fil that in the dawenynge
Chaunte cleer among his wyuys alle
Sat on his perc • e that was in the halle
And next hym sat his faire Pertelote
This chaunte cleer gan to grone in his throte

As a man in his dreme is drecchid
• ore
And whanne that Pertelot thus herde hym rore
She was agast and sayde herte dere
What eylith yow to grone in this manere
Ye be a verry sleper fy for shame
And he answerde thus Madame
I pray yow that ye take it not in greef
Be god I mette I was in such myschief
Right now that myn herte is sore a fright
Now god my sweuen he recche a right
And kepe my body out of foul prisoun
I mette that I romed vp and doun
With ynne our yerde where I saw a b • st
Was lyk an hounde & wolde haue made a reste
Vp on my body and wolde haue had me ded
His colour was betwixt yelow and reed
And tippyd was his tayl and bothe his eris
With blak vnlike the remenaunt of his heris
His snowte smal with glowyng eyen tweye
Yet for his loke almost for feer I deye
This causith me my gronyng doutles
Awey quod she fy for shame hertlees
Allas quod she for be god aboue
Now haue ye lost myn herte & al my loue
I can not loue a cowarde be my feyth
For certis what so ony womman seith
We alle desiren̄ yf it myghte be
To haue husbondis hardy wyse and fre
And secret and non nygard ne no fool
Ne hym that is agast of euery tool
Ne none auauntour be god aboue
How durst ye sey for shame vnto your loue
That ony thing mighte make you a feerde
Haue ye no mannys herte & haue a berde
Allas and conne ye be a ferd of sweuenys
No thing but vainte god woot in sweuene is
Sweuenys engendren of replexion̄
And of synne and of complexion̄
Wh • n humours been to habundaunt in a wight
Certis this dreme whiche ye haue met to nyght
I telle yow trouthe ye may trust me
Cometh of your suꝑfluyte & rede colour parde
Whiche cause folk to drede in her dremys
Of • rowes and of fyre with rede lemys
Of grete bestes that wole hem byte
And alle as a Iape not worth a myte
Right as the humour of Melancolye
Causeth many a man in slepe to crye
For feer of grete bolis and beris blake
Or ellis blake deuylles wol hem take
Of humours coude I telle also
That worken a man in slepe mykyl wo
But I wil passe as lightly as I can
Lo Caton whiche that was a wyse man
Sayde he not thus • do no fors of dremys
Now sir quod she whan we fle fro the bemys
For goddis loue as takith sum laxatif
Vp peryl of my soule and my lif
That bothe of coler and of malencolye
Ye purge you and for ye shul not tary
Though in this toun be non apotecary
I shal my self two herbis teche yow
That shal be for your hele & for your prow
And in your yerd tho herbis shal I fynde
The whiche haue of her proper kynde
To purge you benethe and eke aboue
Foryet not this for goddis owen loue
Ye be right colerik of complexion̄
Where the sonne is in his ascension̄
Ne fynde ye not of humours hote
For yf ye do I dar ley a grote
Thanne shal ye haue a feuyr terciane
Or an agew that may be your bane
A day or two ye shul haue digestyuys
Of wormys or ye take your laxatiuys
Of laureal centory and of fumetory
Or ellis of the elderberyes that growyn ther b •
Of Catapuce or of gaytre beryes
Of herbe yue growyng in your yerd that mery is
Pluk hem vp as they growe and ete hem yn̄
Be mery husbond for your fadir kyn̄
Dredith no dreme I can say you nomore
Madame quod he gramercy of your lore
But natheles as touching Catoun
That of wisedom hath suche a gret renoun
That he bad no dremys forto drede
Be god men may in olde bokis rede
Of many aman more of auctorite
Than •• yr Caton was so moot y the
That al the reuers sayth of his sentence
And haue wel founde be experience
That dremys be significaciouns
As wel of ioye as of tribulacions
That folk enduryn in this lyf present
Ther nedith to make of this non̄ argument
The verry preef shewith it in dede
One of the grettest auctor that men rede
Saith thus that sumtyme two felowis went
On pilgremage in ful good entent
And happid so they comyn in a toun
Where as ther was suche congregacion
Of pepyl and eke of streit herbegage
That they ne fond as mykyl as a cotage
In whiche they bothe mighte I loggid be
Wherfore they muste of necessite
As for that nyght departe companye
And eche of them goth to his osterye
And took his loggyng as it wold falle
That on of hem was loggid in a stalle
Ferre in the yerde with oxen of the plow
That othir man was loggid wel ynow
As was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouernyth al as in comune
And so it be fyl longe or it were day
This man mette in his bed there that he lay
That his felow gan to hym calle
And sayde allas for in an oxes stalle
This nyght shal I be murdrid there I ly
Now help me dere brother or I dy
In alle haste com to me he sayde
This man out of his slepe for feer abreyde
And whanne he was wakid of his slepe
He turned hym and took of this no kepe
Hym thoughte his dreme was but avanyte
Thus twyse in his slepe dremyd he
And atte thridde tyme yet his felaw
Cam as hym thoughte & sayde I am now slawe
Behold my blody woundis depe and wyde
Aryse vp erly in the morow tyde
And atte west gate of the toun quod he
A cartful of dung there shalt thou se
In whiche my body is hid ful pryuely
Do that carte areste boldely
My gold causid my deth soth to sayn̄
And tolde hym euery poynt how he was slayn̄
With a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And trust wel his dreme he fond right trewe
For on the morow as sone as it was day
To his felowis yn he took the way
And whenne that he cam to the oxis stalle
Aftir his felow he gan to calle
The Osteler answerd hym anon̄
And sayde sire your felow is goon̄
As sone as day he wente out of the toun
This man gan fallyn in suspessioun
Remembryng of his dremys that he mette
And forth he goth no lengir wolde he • lette
Vnto th • westgate of the toun and fond
A dong carte as it were to donge londe
That was arayd in the same wyse
As ye haue herd the ded man deuyse
And with hardy herte he gan to crye
Vemaunce and Iustice of this felonye
My f • low murdrid is this same nyght
And in this carte he lieth gapyng vp right
I 〈◊〉 out on the mynistres quod he
That sholde kepe and reu •• this cyte
Harow allas h • re lieth my felow slayn
What sh • lde • more of this tale sayn
The pepyl out sterte & cast the carte to grounde
And in t • e myddel of the dong they fonde
The ded man that murdrid was al newe
O bl • sful god that art so good and trewe
Lo how that thow bewreyest murdir alwey
Murdir wol out that se we day be day
Murdir is so waltsom and abhomynabyl
To god that Iust is and resonable
That he ne wol it suffre helyd to be
Though it abyde aday or two or thre
Murdir wol out this is my conclusion̄
And right anon the mynystris of the toun
Haue hent the carter & so sore hym pyned
And eke the Osteler so sore engyned
That they beknew hir wickydnesse anon
And weren an hangid be the necke boon
Here may ye se that dremys ben to drede
And certis in the same lif I rede
Right in the nexte chappitre aftir this
I gab not so haue I ioye and blis
Two men that wolde haue passid ouer these
For certayn causis in to a fer contre
Yf the wynd ne hadde be contrarye
That made hem in a cyte to tarye
That stood ful mery vp on an hauen syde
But on aday ayens an euyn tyde
The wynd gan chaunge & blew as hym lyst
Ioly and glad they wentyn to rest
And cast hem ful erly forto saylle
But herkyn to that on man fil a greet meruaylle
The on of hem slepinge as he lay
He mette a wonder dreme agayn the day
Hym thoughte a man stood by his beddis syde
And hym com̄aundid that he sholde abyde
And sayde hym thus yf thou to morow wende
Thou shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He wook and tolde his felow what he mette
And prayde hym his viage forto le • te
As for that day he prayde hym forto abyde
His felow that lay be his beddis syde
Gan forto lawhe and scornyd hym ful faste
No dreme quod he may do my herte agaste
That I wol lette forto so my thingis
I set nat a strawe for thy dremyngis
For sweu • nys be but vaintees and Iapes
Men metyn alday of owlis and of apes
And of many amase therwith al
And dremyn of thing that neuir was ne shal
But sith I se that thou wolt here abyde
And thus slouthen wilfully thy tyde
God woot it rewith me and haue good day
And thus he took his leue & wente his way
But er he hadde half his cours ysayled
I not why ne what myschaunce it aylyd
But casuelly the shippis botom to rent
And ship and man vnder the watir it went
In sighte of othir shippis besyde
That with hym sayled atte same tyde
And therfore faire Pertelot so dere
By ensamplis olde maist thou here
That noman sholde be to recheles
Of dremys for I say the dontles
That many a dreme sul sore is forto drede
Lo in the lyf of saint Kenelme I rede
That was Kenulphus sone the nobil kyng
Of mereturik how kenelme mette a thing
A lityl or he were mordrid on aday
His mordir in his vision he say
His norice hym expouned it eueridell
His sweuyn and bad hym kepe hym wel
Fro treson but he was but .vij. yeer old
And therfore lityl tale he hath therof told
Of ony dreme so holy was his herte
Be god I hadde leuyr than my sherte
That ye hadde herd his legend as haue I
Dame Pertelot I say to yow trewly
Macrobius that writtith the visioun
In his book of the dremes of scipioun
Affermyth dremys and saith that they been̄
Warnyng of thingis that we aftir seen̄
And ferthermore I pray yow lokith wel
In the olde testament of daniel
Yf he held dremys ony vainte
Rede eke of Ioseph and there shul ye se
Wondris ben som tyme but I say not al
Warnyng of thingis that shul aftir fal
Lo of Egipt the kyng that hight Pharao
His baker and eke his boteler also
Whethir they felt non effect in dremys
Who so wol seke actis of sondry remys
May rede of dremys awondir thing
Lo Cresus whiche was of lide kyng
Mette he not that he sat vp on a tre
Which signified he sholde hangid be
Lo Andrometa Hectors wif
That day that Hector sholde lese his lif
She dremyd in the same nyght beforn̄
How that the lif of Hector shold be lorn̄
Yf that day he wente vn to bataille
She warned hym but it might not auay • le
He wente forto fighte natheles
But he was slayn anone of Achilles
But that tale is to longe to telle

And
• ek it is nygh day I may not dwelle
Shortly I say as for conclusion̄
That I shal haue of this avision̄
Aduersite and I say furthermore
That I ne telle of laxatiuis no store
For they be venemous I woot it weel
I hem diffye I loue hem neuyr adeel
But now lete vs speke of mirthe & stynt al this
Madame Pertelot so haue I blis
Of o thing god hath me sent large grace
For when I see the beaute of your face
Ye be so skarlet reed aboute your yen
It maketh al my drede forto dien
For also sikir as in principio
Mulier est hommis confusio
Madame the sentence of this latyn is
Womman is mannys Ioie and his blis
For when I fele an nyght your softe syde
Al be it that y may not on you ryde
For that our perche is made so narow allas
I am so ful of ioye and of solas
That y diffye bothe sweuene and dreme
And with that word he fley doun fro the beem
For it was day and eek his hennys alle
And with a chuk he gan hem doun calle
For he had founde a corn̄ lay in the yerde
Ryal he was and nomore a ferde
He federyd Pertelot twenty tyme
And trade as ofte or it was pryme
He lokith as he were a grym •• oun
And on his toos he romed vp an doun
Hym deyned not to sette his feet to grounde
Ay he chuckid whenne he hadde a corn̄ y founde
And to hym thanne ran his wyuys alle
As ryal as a prince in his halle
Leue I this chauntcleer in his pasture
And aftir wol I telle of his auenture
Whan the moneth in the whiche the •••• de began
That highte march that god first made man
Was complet and passid were also
Sith marche began thritty dayes and two
Be • il that chauntecleer in al his pryde
His seuyn wyuys walkyng hym beside
Cast vp his yen to the bright sonne
That in the signe of taurus was I ronne
Twenty degrees & oon̄ and sumwhat more
He knew be kynde and be non other •• re
That it was pryme & crew with a blisful steuyn
The sonne he sayde is clombe vp to heuyn
Fourty degrees & one & sumwhat more I wys
Madame Pertelote my worldis blis
Harkyn how this blisful briddis synge
And se the fressh flouris how they sprynge
Ful is myn herte of reuel and sol • s
But sodenly hym fil a sorouful caas
For euer the latter ende of ioye is woo
And comynly often tyme it f • llith so
And if a rethour coude faire endite
He in a cronycle myghte sauely wryte
As for a souereyn notabilyte
Now euery wyseman herkyn to me
This story is al so trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelot delake
That wommen holden in ful gret reuerence
Now wol I turne ayen to my sentence
A col fox ful of sleyghte and iniquite
That in the groue hadde woned yeris thre
Be high ymaginacion aforn̄ cast
The same nyght thorough the hegge brast
Into the yerd there chauntecleer the faire
Was wont and eke his wyuys to repaire
And in a bed of wortis stille he lay
T • l it was passid vndren of the day
Waytinge his tyme on chauntecleer to falle
As gladly doon thise homicides alle
That in a wayte ligge to murdre men
A fals murderour ruckyng in thy den
O newe Scariot and newe Genylion̄
Fals dissinnlour o greek Synon̄
That broughtist troye vttirly to sorow
O chauntecleer acursid be the merow
That thou in thy yerde fley fro the bemys
Thow were ful wel warnyd be thy dremys
That ilke day was perilous to the
But that god afore woot muste nedis be
Aftir the oppinion of certeyn clerkis
Witnes of hym that ony clerk is
That in scole is gret altercacion̄
In this mater and gret disputacion̄
And hath ben of an hundrid thousand men
But I ne can not bulte out the brenne
As can the holy doctour Austyn̄
Or boece or the bisshop Bradwardyn̄
Whethir that goddis wil afore wetynge
Streynyth me needles to do a thing
Nedly clepe I simpyl necessite
Or yf the fre choys be grauntyd me
To do that same thing or do it nought
Though god forwoot it or it was wrought
Or yf his witynge streyneth neuyr adeel
But by necessite condicionel
I wol not haue to doon̄ of suche matere
My tale is of a cok as ye shul here
That took his counceyl of his wif with sorow
To walke in the yerde vp on the morow
That he hadde met the dreme as I you tolde
Womennys counceyllis be ful ofte colde
Womannys counceyl broughte vs first to w ••
And made adam fro paradis to go
There as he was ful mery and wel at ese
But for I not whom I mighte displese
Yf I counceyl of wommen wolde blame
Passe ouer I sayde it in my game
Redith auctours where they trete of suche matere
And what they say of wommen ye mowe her •
These been the cokkis wordis and not myn
I can no harm of no womman deuyne
Faire in the sonde to bathe hir merily
Lith P • rtel • t and alle h • r susteris by
Ayens ye sonne and chauntecleer so free
Sang merier than the marmayde in the see
For Phisalogus sayth vttirly
How that they syngen wel and merily
And so be fil as he cast his ye
Among the wortis on a boterflye
He was waar of this fox that lay ful lowe
No th • ng than lust 〈◊〉 forto crowe
But cr • de anon cok cok and vp he stert

• s man that was afrayd
〈◊〉 his hert
For naturelly a best desirith to fle
Fro h • s contrary yf he may it se
Th • ugh he neuyr had seyn it erst with his ye
This c • auntec •• er wh • n he gan hym aspye
He wolde haue fled but that the fox anon
Sayde gentyl sire allas what wyl ye don
Be ye affraid of me that am your fr •• de
Certis sire than be ye vnkynd
If I to you wolde harm or vilonye
I am not comyn your counseyl to aspye
But trewly the cause of my comynge
Was only to here how ye syng
For trewly ye h • ue as mery a steuyn
As ony aungel hath that is in heuyn
Therwith ye haue of musik more felynge
Than hadde voys or ony that can syng
My lord your fadir god his soule blis
And eke your moder of her gentilnes
Haue in my hous be ful wel at ese
And certes sire fayne wolde I you plese
But for men speke of syngyng I wolde sey
So moot I browkyn myn yen twey
Saue you ne herd I neuer man so synge
As did your fader in the mornynge
Certis it was of herte al that he song
And forto make his voys the more strong
He wolde so peyne hym that with bothe his yen̄
He muste wynke so lowde he muste cryen̄
And stondyn on his tiptoos therwith all
And strecche forth his necke long and smal

And
• ek he was of suche discrecion̄
That ther was noman in no region̄
That hym in song or wisdom mighte passe

I haue wel
• ed dan burnel the asse
Among his vers ther was a cok
For a prestis sone yaf hym a knok
Vp on is leggis while he was yong & ny ••
He made hym forto lese his benefice
But ther is no comparison̄
Betwix the wisdom and discrecion
Of your fadir and of his subtilyte
Now syngith sire for saint charite
Lete se can ye your fadir countirfete
This chauntecleer his wyngis gan bete
As man that coude nat his reson aspye
So was he rauysshed with his flaterye
Allas ye lordis many a fals flaterour
Is in your court and meny a fals losingour
That plese you more be my feith
Than he that sothfastnes vnto you saith
Redith ecclesiast of flaterye
Bewaar ye lordis of her trecherye
This chauntecleer stood hye vp on his toos
Strecching his necke and held his yen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde for the nonys
And dan russell start vp at onys
And by the gorge hente chauntecleer
And on his bak toward the wode hym beer

For yet was ther noman that hym
• ued
O destene that maist not be eschued
Allas that chauntecleer fley fro the bemys
Allas his wyf raught not of dremys
And on a friday fil al this myschaunce
O venus that art god of plesaunce
Sithnes that thy seruan̄t was this chauntecleer
And in thy seruise dide al his power
More for delite than the worlde to multiplye
Why woldist thou suffre hym on thy day to dye
O Gaufryde dere maistir souereyn
That whan the worthy kyng richard was sleyn
With shot complemedist his deth so sore
Why ne hadde I now thy sentence & thy lore
The friday forto childen as did ye
For on a friday shortly slayn was he
Thanne wolde I shewe you how that I coude pleyn
For chauntecleer and for his peyn̄
Certis suche crye ne lamentacion̄
Nas of ladies maad whenne Ilion was wonne
And pirrus with his bright swerd
When he hent kyng Pryam be the berd
And slow hym as saith Eneydos
As maden alle the hennys in the cloos
Whenne that they hadde of chauntecler the sight
But souerenly dame Pertelot gan to shright
Ful lowder than did hasdrubalis wif
Whenne that her husbond had lost his lif
And that the romayns had brent Cartage
She was so ful of turment and of rage
That wilfully in to the fire she stert
And brende her self with a stedfast hert
O woful hennys so that cryden ye
As whenne that Nero brent the cyte
Of rome criden the Senatouris wyuys
For that her husbondis sholde lese her liuys
Withoutyn gilt Nero hath hem sleyn̄
Now wol I turne to my tale agayn̄
This sely widow and hir deughtris two
Herden the hennys crye and make woo
And out at the dore stert they anone
And saw the fox toward the wode goon̄
And baar vp on his bak the cok awey
And criden out and harow and welawey
A ha the fox and aftir hym they renne
And eek with staues meny othir menne
Ran colle our dogge talbot and garlonde
And malkyn with her distaf in her honde
Ran • ow and eek the very hoggis
For they so sore a ferd were of the doggis
And showtyng of men & of wommen eek
They ronne so her herte thoughte to breke
Th • y yellyn as fendis doon in helle
The doggis criden as men wolde hem quelle
Out of the h • uys com the swarm of bees
The gees for feer fley ouer the trees
So hidons was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iacke Straw ne his meyne
Ne made neuir showtes half so shrylle
When that they wolde ony flemyng kylle
As that day was maad vp on the fox
Of b • as they blew the trompes & of box
Of horn & boon in whiche they powpyd
And therwith they shrikyd and shoutyd
It semed as though heuyn sholde falle
Now godemen I pray you harkyn alle
Lo how fortune turnyth sodenly
The hope and the pryde of her enuy
This cok that laye vp on this foxis bak
In al his drede vnto the fox he spak
And sayde sire yf I were as ye
Yet sholde I say as wis god help me
Turnyth ay • en ye proude chorlis alle
A verry pestilence vp on you falle
Now am I come vnto this wodis side
Magre your hed the cok shal here abyde
I wol hym ete in feith and that anon̄
The fox answerde in feith it shal be doon̄
And as he spak the word al sodenly
This cok brak from his mouth deliuerly
And high vp on a tree he fly anon̄
And whenne the fox saw that he was goon̄
Alas quod he o chauntecler alas
I haue do to you gret trespas
In as muche as I made you a ferde
Whenne I you hente & broughte out of your yerde
But syre I did hit not in no wickid entent
Com doun & I shal telle you what I ment
I shal you say soth so god helpe me so
Nay thanne quod he I shrewe vs bothe two
And first I shrewe my self bothe blood & bonys
Yf thou begyle me ofter thanne onys
Thou shalt nomore with thy flaterye
Do me synge with a wynkyng ye
For he that wynketh whanne he sholde se
As wisly god lete hym neuyr the
Nay quod the fox god yeue hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaunce
That iangelith whe • that he sholde haue p • es
Lo suche it is forto be recheles
And negligent and truste on flaterye
But ye that holdyn this tal • a foly •
As of a fox and a cok and an hen
Takith the moralite gode men
For saint Poule saith al that writyn is
To our doctryne is writyn y wis
Takith the fruyt & leet the chaf be stille
Now gode men yf that it be your wille
As seith my lorde so make vs alle good men
And bringe vs to his high blisse amen

lg.head: ¶Here begynneth the Mauncipelis prolog.
lg.l: WOot ye not where ther stōdith a litil toun
Whiche that is clepid bob vp and doun
Vnder the blee in Cauntirbery wey
There gan our oste to • ape and to pley
And sayde s • res what don is in the myre
Is th • r noman for praier ne for hire
That wol awake our felaw behynde
A th • ef mighte hym ful lightly ro • be & bynde
Se • ow • e nappeth se for cokkis bonys
How 〈◊〉 wol falle from his hors attonys
Is th • t a cook of london with myschaunce
Do h • m comfort he knoweth his penaunce
For he shal telle a tale be my fey
Al though it be not worth a botel hey
Awa • e thou cook qd he god yeue the sorow
What eylith the to slepe be the morow
Hast thow had fleen al night or art thou dronk
Or hast thou al night with som quene y swonke
So that thow maist not holde vp thy hed
This cook that was ful paal & no thing reed
Sayde our hoost so god my soule blis
Ther is falle on me greet henynes
Not I nat why. me were leuer to slepe
Than the best galon of wyne in chepe
Wel quod the Mauncipyl yf it may do the ese
To the sir cook and to no wight disp ••• e
Whiche that here riden in this company
And that our hoost wil of his curtesy
I wol as now excuse the of thy tale
For in good feith thy visage is ful • ale
Thyn yen dasowen sothly as me thinkith
And wel I woot thy breth ful foule stynketh
That shewith wel thou art not wel disposid
Of me certeyn thou shalt not be glosid
Se how he galpith lo this dronkyn wight
As though he wolde swelle anon right
Hold cloos thy mouth be thy fader kyn
The deuyl of helle sette his foot ther yn
Thy cursid breth enfectith vs alle
Fy stynkyng swyn foule moot the b • falle
Takith he de sires of this lusty man
Now swete sire wol ye iuste atte van
Therto me thinkith ye be wel y shape
I trow that ye haue dronkyn wyn of ape
And that is when men pleyen a • te straw
And with his speche the cook wexid alwraw
And on the Mauncipyl he gan to nodde faste
For lak of speche adoun the hors hym caste
Where as he lay til that men hym vp took
This was a feir cheuesaunce of a cook
Alas that he ne had holde hym be his ladyl
And er that he ayen were in his sadyl
Ther was a gret shouyng bothe to and fro
To lifte hym vp and mykyl care and woo
So vnweldy was this sely pallyd gost
And to the mauncipyl than spak our ost
Be cause that drynke hath dominacion̄
Op on this man be my sauacion̄
I trow lewdly wil he telle his tale
For were it wyne or old moisty ale
That he hath dronkyn he spekith so in his nose
And fuesith faste and eke he hath the pose
He hath also to do more than ynough
To kepe hym on his Capyl out of the slough
And if he falle from his Capil eft sone
Than shul we alle haue ynough to done
In liftyng vp his dronkyn corps
Tel on thy tale of hym y make I nofors
But yet mauncipyl in feyth thou art to nyce
Thus opynly to reproue hym of his vice
Anothir day he wyl pauenture
Recleyme the and brynge the to lure
I mene he speke wol of smale thingis
And forto pynche at thy rekenyngis
That were not honest yf it cam to the preef
No qd the Mauncipil that were a gret myschief
So mighte he brynge me in to the snare
Yet hadde y leuer paye for the mare
Whiche he ridith on than he shulde with me stryue
I wol not wrath hym so mote I th • yue
That I spak I sayde it but in bourde
And wite ye wel I haue here in my gourde
A draughte of wyne ye of a ryp • grape
And right anone ye shul se a good Iape
This cook shal drynke therof yf I may
Vp on my lif he wol not say nay
And certenly to tellen as it was
Of this vessel the cook drank faste alas
What nedith it he drank ynough • eforn̄
And when he hadde poupid in h • s horn̄
To the mauncip • l he took the gourde agayn
And of the drynke the cook was ful fayn
And thankid hym in suche wyse as he coude
Than gan our ost to lanwghe wonder loude
And sayde I se wel it is necessary
Where þ• we goon good drynke with vs to cary
For that wol turne rancour and d • s • s •
To accorde and loue & many a word to • ese
O bacus bliss • d be thy name
That so canst turne ernest in to game
Worship and thank be to thy deyte
Of that mater ye get nomore of me
Tel on thy tale thou maun •• pil I the prey
Wel sire quod • e herkenyth what I say
lg.trailer:
¶Here endith the Maun •• plis
•• olog. ¶And begynnyth his tale.

lg.l:
WHen Phebus dwellid
〈…〉 a doun
As olde bokis maken mencion
He was the most lusty bacheler
Of al the worlde and eke the beste archer
He slough Pheton the serpent as he lay
Slepyng ayens the sonne vp on a day
And many anothir nobil dede
He with his bowe wrought as men mowe rede
Pleye he coude on euery mynstralcye
And syngen that it was a melodye
To here of his cleer vois the soun
Certes the kyng of Thebes amphion
That with his song wallid the cyte
Coude neuer synge half so wel as he
Therto he was the semelist man
That is or was sith the worlde began
What nedith it his feture forto discryue
For in this worlde was ther non so fair a liue
He was therwi • h fulfillid of gentilnsse
Of honour and of parfyt worthynesse
This Phebus that was flour of bachelerye
As wel in fredom as in chiualrye
For disporte in signe eek of victorye
Of Pheton so as tellith vs the story
Was wont to bere in his hond abowe
Now hadde this Ph • bus in his hous a crowe
With ynne a cage y fost • id many a day
And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
Wh • t was this crowe as is a snow whit swan
And countir • etid the speche of euery man
He coude whan he sholde telle a tale
Ther was in al this worlde non nyghtyngale
Ne coude be an hundrid thousand deel
Synge so wonderly merily and weel
Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
Whiche that he loued more than his lif
And nyght and day did euer his diligence
Here forto plese and do her reuerence
Saue only the soth yf I shal sayn
Ielous he was and wolde haue kept her feyn
For hym were loth iapid forto be
And so is euery wight in suche degre
But al for nought for it auaylid nought
A good wyf that is cleen of werk and thought
Sholde not be kept in non awe certeyn
And trewly the more it is in veyn
To kepe a shrewe for it wol nat be
This holde I for a very nycete
To spille labour forto kepe wyuys
Thus writen olde clerkis in her lyuys
But now to purpos as I first began
This worthy Phebus doth al that he can
To plesen her wenyng thorow suche plesaunce
And for his manhood & for his gouernaunce
That noman sholde put hym from hir grace
But god it woot ther may noman enbrace
As to distreyne a thing whiche that nature
Hath naturelly set in a creature
Take ony brid and put hym in a Cage
And do al thyn entent and thy corage
To fostre it tenderly with mete and drynke
Of alle deyntees that thou canst bethinke
And kepe it al so clenly as thou may
Al though his cage of gold be neuer so gay
Yet hath this brid by twenty thousand fold
Leuer in a f • rest that is wilde and cold
Go ete wormys and suche wrecchidnes
For euer this brid wol do his besynes
To ascape out of his cage when he may
His liberte the brid desirith ay
Leet take a cat and fostre hir with mylk
And tender flesh and make her couche of silk
And leet her se a mous go by the wal
Anon she we • uith flesh and couche and al
And euery deynte that is in that hous
Suche appetit hath she to ete the mous
Lo here hath lust his domynacion
And appetit flemyth discrecion
As the wolf hath also a vilens kynde
The lewdist wolf that she may fynde
Or le • st of reputacion that wol she take
In tyme when her lust to haue a make
Alle thyse ensamplis speke I be thyse men
That been vntrewe and no thing by women
For men haue euer a licorous appetit
On lower thing to • fourme her delit
Than on her wyuys be they neuer so feir
Ne neuer so trewe ne so deboneir
Flesh is so newfangil with myschaunce
That we ne konne in no thing haue plesaunce
That sounyth vnto vertu ony whyle
Thus Phebus whiche thoughte no gyle
Disceyued was for al his iolyte
For vnder hym another had she
A man of litil reputacion
Not worth to hym in no comparison
The more harm is it happith ofte so
Of whiche ther comyth muche harm and woo
And so befyl when Phebus was absent
His wyf anon hath for her lemman sent
Her lemman certis that is a knauyssh speche
Foreyne it me that I you beseche
The wyse Plato saith as ye mowe rede
The word muste nede accorde with the dede
Yf men shul telle propirly a thing
The word muste cosyn be to the workynge
I am a boistous man right thus say I
Ther is but litil difference trewly
Betwix a wyf that is of high degre
Yf of her body dishonest she be
And a pore wenche other than this
Yf it so be they worke bothe amys
But that the gentil is in staat aboue
She shal be clepid his lady and his loue
And for that other is a power woman
She shal be clepid his wenche or his lemman
And god it woot myn owen dere brother
Men leye as lowe that on as that othir
Right so betwix an open teraunt
And an out lawe or a theef erraunt
The same I say ther is no difference
To Alisaundir was told this sentence
That for the tiraunt is of gretter might
Beforce of meyne to sle doun right
And brenne hous & hoom & make al pleyn
Lo therfore is he clepid a capteyn
And for the outlawe hath but smal meyne
And may not do so gret harm as he
Ne brynge a contre to so greet myschief
Men clepe hym an outlawe or a theef
But for I am a man not textuel
I wol not of this trete neuer a deel
I wol go to my tale as I began
Whan Phebus wyf had sent for her lemman
Anon they wroughten alle their lust volage
This whyte crowe that hyng ay in the cage
Beheld her work and sayde neuer aworde
And when hoom was come Phebus the lord
This crowe song cuckow cuckow
What b • id quod Phebus what syngist thow
Ne were thou not wont so merily to synge
That to my hert it was a reioysing
To here this vois allas what song is this
Be god quod he y synge not amys
Phebus quod h • for al thy worthynes
For al thy beaute and thy gentilnes
For al thy song and thy myns • ral • ye
For al thy waytyng blerid is thyn ye
With one of litil reputacion
Not worth to the in no comparison
The mountaunce of a gnat so moot I thryue
For on thy bed thy wyf I saw hym swyue
What wol ye more the crowe anon hym tolde
By sad tokenys and by wordis bolde
How that his wyf hadde don her lecherye
Hym to gret shame and to gret vilonye
And tolde hym eft he saw it with his yen
This Phebus gan a weyward forto prien
Hym thoughte his herte brest a two
His bowe he bent and set ther ynne a flo
And in his Ire he hath his wyf slayn
This is the effect ther is nomore to sayn
For sorow he brak his mynstra • sie

Bothe harp •
and lute / geterne and sawtrie
And eek he brak his arowis and his bowe
And aftir that thus spak he to the crowe
Traitour quod he with tunge of scorpion
Thou hast me brought to my confusion
Alas that I was wrought why nere I ded

O dere wyf O gemme of lusty
• eed
That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
Now liest thou d • d with face pale of • ewe
Ful giltlees that durste I swere • wys
O rakyl hond to do so foule amys
O troubil wit O Ire recheles
That vnauysid synnyst giltlees
O wantrust ful of suspecion
Where was thy wit and thy discrecion
O euery man bewaar of rekilnes
Ne trow no thing withoute witnes
Smyt not to sone or thou wite why
And be auysid wel and sikirly
Or ye do ony execucion
Vp on your Ire for suspecion
Allas a thousand folk haue rekil Ire
Fully fordoon & brought hem in the myre
Allas for sorow I wil my self sle
And to the crowe o false theef sayde he
I wol quyte anon thy fals tale
Thou song whylom lik an nyghtyngale
Now shalt thou fals theef thy song forgoon
Eke thy whyte fetheris euerichon
Ne neuer in al thy lif shalt thou speke
Thus shulle men on a treytour be a wreke
Th • u and thyn ofspring euer shul be blake
Ne neuer swete noyse shul ye make
But euer cr • e ayens tempest and rayn
In tokyn that thorou the my wif is sleyn
And to the crowe he stert and that anone
And pullid of his whit fetheris euerichon
And made hym blak and reft hym al his song
And eke his speche & out a • te dore hym slong
Vnto the deuyl whiche I hym betake
And for this caas be alle crowis blake
Lordingis by this ensampyl I wol you pray
Bewar and take kepe what I say
Ne tellith neuer noman in your lif
How that anothir man hath dight his wyf
He wyl you haten mortally certeyn
Salamon as wyse clerkis sayn
Techith a man to kepe his tunge wel
But natheles thus taughte me my dame
My sone think on the crowe a goddis name
My sone keep wel thy tunge and kep thy frend
A wickid tunge is worse than a fend
My sone from a fend men may hem blisse
My sone god of his endles godnesse
Wallid a tonge with teth and lippis eek
For man sholde hym auyse what he speek
My sone ful ofte forto mykyl speche
Hath many a man be spilt as clerkis teche
But for litil speche spoken auysedly
Is noman shent to speke generally
My sone thy tonge sholdist thou restreyne
At al tyme but whan thou dost thy peyn •
To speke of god in honour here
The firste vertu sone yf thou wolt lere
Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tunge
Thus lerne childryn when they be yong
My sone of mykyl spekyng vn auysid
There lasse spekyng hadde I now suffisid
Comyth mykyl harm thus was me taught
In mykyl speche synne wantith nought
Wost thou wherfore a rakil tonge seruith
Right as a swerd for cuttith and forkeruith
An arm a two my dere sone right so
A tonge cuttith frendship al a two
A Iangelar is to god abhominabil
Rede Salamon so wyse and honourabil
Rede Dauid and his psalmys rede Seneke
My sone spek not ne with thy hed thou beke
Dissimyl as thou were deef yf that thou here
The Iangelour spekith of parlous matere
The flemyng saith lerne yf that thou list
That litil Iangelyng causith muche rest
My sone yf thou no wickid word hast said
The dar not drede for to be by wraid
But he that hath myssaid I dar wel sayn
He may by no way clepe his word agayn
Thing that is said / is said & forth it goth
Though h • m re • ente or hym be neuer so loth
He is thra • le to hym to whom he hath said
A tale for w • i • he he is now euyl a paid
My son bewaar and be non auctor newe
Of tidingis whethir they be fals or trewe
Where so thou come among hye or lowe
Kepe wel thy tonge and think on the crowe
lg.trailer: ¶Here endith th • Maunciplis tale. ¶Here be • ynneth the Parsonnys prolog

lg.l: BY that the Mauncipil had his tale endid
The sonne f • o the south syde is descendid
So lowe that hit was to my sight
Degrees of fyue and twenty of highte
Ten atte clocke it was so as I gesse
For enleuyn foot a litil more or lesse
My shadow was at that tyme as there
Of suche feet as my lengthe partid were
In .vj. feet equally of proporcion
Ther with the monys exaltacion
I mene libra alwey gan ascende
As we were entring atte townys ende
For whiche our ost as he was wont to gye
As in this caas this ioly companye
Sayde in this wyse lordingis euerichon̄
Now lakkith vs no tale more than on̄
Fulfillid is my sentence and my decre
Who wol now telle a tale let se
Almost fulfillid is myn ordenaunce
I pray to god so yeue hym right good chaunce
That tellith this tale to vs lustely
Sire preest quod he art thou a vicary
Or art thou a parson say soth be thy fey
Be what thou be breke not our pley
For euery man saue thou hath told his tale
Vnbokil and shew vs what is in thy male
For trewly me thynkith be thy chere
Thou sholdest knytte vp wel a greet matere
Tel vs a fabil anon for cokkis bonys
This Parson answerde al attonys
Thou getist fabil non told for me
For Poule that writith to Timothe
Repreueth hem that weyuen sothfastnesse
And techyn fablis and suche wrecchidnesse
Why sholde I sowe draf out of my fist
When I may sowe whete yf me list
For whiche I say yf that thou list to here
Moralite and of vertuous matere
And than yf ye wol yeue me audience
I wolde ful fayn at cristis reuerence
Done you plesaunce leesful as I can
But trustith wel I am a sotheryn man
I can nat geste rum ram ruf by lettir
And god woot ryme holde I but litil bettir
And therfore yf ye lust I wol nat glose
I wol you telle a mery tale in prose
To knit vp al this fest and make an ende
And Ihesu f • r his grace wit me sende
To shewe you the wey in this viage
Of that ilke parfyt glorius pilgremage
That highte Ierusalem celestial
And yf ye vouchesauf anone I shal
Begynne vp on my tale for whiche I preye
Tel your auys I can no better seye
But natheles this meditacion
I put it ay vnder correction
Of clerkis for I am not textuel
I take but the sentence trustith weel
Therfore I make protestacion
That I wol stonde to correction
Vp on this word we haue assentid sone
For as it semed it was forto done
To enden in som vertuous sentence
And forto yeue hym place and audience
And bad to our ost he sholde to hym sey
That alle we to telle his tale hym preye
Our oste hadde the wordis for vs alle
Sir preest quod he now fair moot you befalle
Saith what ye list and we shul gladly here
And with that word he sayde in this manere
Tellith quod he your meditacion
But hastith you the sonne wol a doun
Beth fructuous and that in litil space
And to do wel god sende you his grace
lg.trailer: ¶Here endith the Parsons prolog. ¶And here begynneth his tale.

div.p:
OVr swete lord god of heuene that noman wil perisshe but wil that we comen alle to the knowleching of him and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable Amonesheth vs by the prophete Ieremye that saith in this wyse / Stondeth vpon the weyes / And see and axe ye • f olde pathis That is to seye of olde sentencis Whiche is good weye / And walketh in that weye And that is refresshyng for your sowlis / Many ben the weyes spirituel that leden folk to our lord Ihesu Crist And to the regne of glorye / Of whiche weyes / ther is a ful noble weye and wel couenable whiche may not faylle to man ne to woman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the right weye of Iherusalem celestial / And this wey is cleped penitence / Of whiche man sholde gladly herkne and enquyre wyth al his •• rte to wete / what is
penytence or penaunce / And wyte whens it is cleped penytence / And how many maners ben the actions of worchyng of penytence / And how many spyces ther be of penitence / And whiche thynges behouen and apperteynen to penytence / Saint Ambrose saith that penytence is the pleynyng of the man for the gilt that he hath do / And nomore to do ony thynge for the whyche hym ought to pleyne / And som doctor saith / that penaunce is the waymenting of man that soroweth f • r his synne And pyneth hym self for he hath mysdon / Penytence with certayn circumstaunce is verray repentance of man that holdeeth hym self in sorow and other peyne for his • giltes / And for he shal be veray penitent / He shal first bewaylen the synnes that he hath don̄ / And stedfastly purpose in his herte to haue shryfte of mouth / And to do satysfactyon and neuer for to do thyng
〈◊〉 whyche hym ought more to bewayle or complayn •
〈…〉 to contynue in good werkes / or ellis his repen ••••• may not auayle / For as saith saint Ysodre He is a Iapar and a gabber and not veray repentant / that eftsones doth thing for whiche hym oweth to repente ne stynte to doo synne / may not auaylle / But natheles men shold take hope that at euery tyme that men falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may aryse thurgh penytence yf he haue grace But certainly it is grete doubte / . For as seyth saint Gregore / vimeth ariseth he out of his synne / that is charged of euyl vsage. And therfore repentaunte folk that stynte for to synne and for to lete synne or synne forlete hem / Holy chirche holdeth hem syker of her saluacyon. /
And he that synneth and verily repentith hym in his las • e Holy chirche hopith his saluacōn by the grete mercy of our
• ord Ihesu Crist for his repentaunce / but take ye the siker
